title-group.article-title: Clinical and endoscopic findings of patients presenting with upper gastrointestinal bleeding in Khartoum, Sudan: a cross-sectional study

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/05dvsnx49grid.440839.20000 0001 0650 6190Faculty of Medicine, AL-Neelain University, Khartoum, Sudan

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Upper gastrointestinal bleeding remains a significant medical emergency with considerable morbidity and mortality rates. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is a key procedure because of its diagnostic and therapeutic value. Understanding the clinical picture as well as the expected endoscopic variations in the area can potentially improve fatal complications. This study aimed to describe the clinical presentations, laboratory findings, and endoscopic patterns of affected patients in a tertiary bleeding centre in Khartoum, Sudan.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: A cross-sectional study was conducted at a bleeding centre in Khartoum, Sudan, and data from 513 patients presenting over 12 months were analysed. Demographic data, clinical presentations, laboratory investigations, and endoscopy outcomes were collected and analysed via appropriate tests at a 95% confidence interval (p value < 0.05).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The study population comprised 369 males (71%) and 144 females (28%), with a mean age of 52 years. Esophageal and gastric varices were prevalent in 311 (60.6%) and 109 (21.2%) of the patients, respectively, whereas a total of 181 (35.3%) had a positive history of schistosomiasis. Esophageal and gastric varices were significantly associated with rebleeding (p-value < 0.001).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Esophageal and gastric varices are the commonest endoscopic findings, with schistosomiasis present as a comorbid condition in one-third of patients. Both conditions are associated with significant recurrence rates. This study highlights the need to address the schistosomiasis burden in Sudan and recommends further studies to follow up on the progress of the condition.

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in Sudan, with an approximately 5–10% mortality rate worldwide [1]. The incidence of UGIB is 80–150 cases per 100,000 people [2]. Bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract is five times more common than bleeding from the lower gastrointestinal tract [3]; mortality predictors include advanced age, haemodynamic instability (hypotension, tachycardia), and comorbidities [4].

Urgent interventions are needed to minimise the fatal risks of this type of emergency. Endoscopy is a well-established method for counteracting the effects of upper gastrointestinal bleeding urgently through methods of ligation or sclerotherapy. However, it is also a valuable tool for diagnosing less urgent causes of intestinal bleeding, such as gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcer disease (gastric and duodenal), gastritis, duodenitis, and gastrointestinal malignancies.

Limited data have been reported regarding risk factors and clinical presentation in Sudan, particularly in recent years. Our study was conducted to address this gap in knowledge and to obtain a better understanding of upper gastrointestinal bleeding patterns in the region. Acquiring serial data on this topic also helps guide and direct official policies.

The study objectives were to describe the demographics of upper gastrointestinal bleeding patients, calculate the prevalence of common endoscopic findings and indications (clinical presentations) among them, describe laboratory findings, and test associations between different variables in a tertiary bleeding centre in Khartoum, Sudan.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: This is a retrospective cross-sectional study carried out at a bleeding centre in Khartoum, Sudan, that explored medical records from January 2022 to December 2022. A total of 2078 emergency upper gastrointestinal endoscopy procedures were performed during those 12 months.

The inclusion criterion for patients was emergency esophagogastroduodenoscopy from January 2022 to December 2022 at the Mohammed Salih bleeding centre, with full endoscopic findings being reported. Any records that did not include esophagogastroduodenoscopy findings were excluded.

Owing to the large volume of paper-based records and limited resources, it was not feasible to include all consecutive eligible patients. Instead, a modified systematic sampling approach was employed: every third patient file from the endoscopy logbook was selected for review. If a selected file was ineligible (e.g., not meeting the inclusion criteria), the next available eligible file was included. This approach was chosen to maximise efficiency while seeking to minimise selection bias under resource constraints. The cross-sectional design was chosen specifically to describe the clinical and endoscopic characteristics of patients and to identify associations between variables at a single point in time, as it is well-suited for these descriptive and analytical aims.

Based on previous literature reporting 90% esophageal varices and assuming a 95% confidence level (Z = 1.96) and a precision of 5% (d = 0.05), the minimum required sample size was calculated to be 139 patients. To increase the study’s power and representation, we included 513 files according to the sampling method described above.

Demographic data (sex, age, residency), clinical presentation, rebleeding episodes, clinical assessment, data about comorbidities, lab investigations, chronic medications, and endoscopic findings were recorded through a standardised digital Google form.

Patients were first haemodynamically stabilised by intravenous fluids, antiemetics, proton pump inhibitors, vasopressors, vitamin K, and blood transfusions as required. Subsequent investigations, including complete blood count, coagulation profile, viral screening, and others, were performed as indicated. Patients were subsequently scheduled for upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Variceal bleeders were sclerosed or band-ligated as appropriate. After endoscopy, haemodynamically stable patients were discharged within 2–3 h unless complications occurred.

Data were collected from a structured database, and entry was performed via Statistical Packages for the Social Sciences version 25. Numerical missing data were handled with multiple imputation under the assumption of missing at random (MAR), generating five imputed datasets. Descriptive statistics were used to summarise the data. Categorical variables are presented as frequencies and percentages, and continuous variables are presented as the means ± standard deviations (SDs). A p-value < 0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance.

The chi-square test was used to examine associations between categorical variables (e.g., sex and the presence of esophageal varices). The unpaired t-test was used to compare continuous variables between two groups (e.g., haemoglobin levels in patients with and without schistosomiasis).

caption.p: Missing values and percentages for each variable

sec.p: Missing data frequencies and percentages are listed in Table 1

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Ethical approval was obtained from the community department, the faculty of medicine at Al-Neelain University, and the centre’s research committee.

sec.title: Consent to participate
sec.p: This study was approved by the local review board and was conducted in accordance with the ethical principles of Helsinki. Because of the retrospective nature of the study, consent was waived by the Ethics Committee of the Mohammed Salih bleeding centre.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Out of the 513 sample studies, 369 were males (71%), and 144 were females (28%), with a male to-female ratio of approximately 3:1 and a pooled mean age of 52.78 (±17.25). On further classification of patients according to their residence, the majority of 241 (47%) were from Khartoum, 156 (30.4%) were from Aljazera state, and 50 (9.7%) were from the White Nile state.
After a complete case analysis was conducted and compared with multiple imputations, the following results (Table 2) were obtained:

caption.p: Comparison of mean values from complete case analysis and multiple imputation models

sec.p: In terms of presenting symptoms, the majority (235, (45.6%)) presented with both haematemesis and melena, 155 (30.2%) with haematemesis alone, 105 (20.5%) with melena only, and 14 (2.7%) with bleeding per rectum. The most common observed examination finding was pallor, which was reported in 253 patients (49.3%), followed by splenomegaly in 112 patients (21.8%), ascites in 56 patients (10.9%), jaundice in 45 patients (8.8%), hepatomegaly in 30 patients (5.8%), abdominal tenderness in 29 patients (5.7%), shrunken liver in 27 patients (5.3%), umbilical hernia in 6 patients (1.2%), lower limb oedema in 4 patients (0.8%), and distended veins in 1 patient (0.2%). The majority of the patients (285; (55.6%)) had a past history of a similar condition, and 116 (22.6%) had a past history of jaundice.

The pooled mean haemoglobin level at presentation was 9.096 (± 5.820) g/dL, whereas the pooled mean platelet count was 168.92 (± 121.364) x 109/L. Drug usage among the study population showed that beta blockers were the most frequent at 20.1%; NSAIDs, antihypertensive, and oral hypoglycemic drugs followed at 13.3%, 5.8%, and 5.3%, respectively

The most identifiable cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding was esophageal varices in 311 (60.6%) patients and was significantly associated with male sex after being assessed by the chi-square test. The second most common cause was gastric varices, 109 (21.2%), followed by gastritis, oesophagitis, gastric ulcers, hiatus hernias, duodenal ulcers, portal hypertension gastropathy, and duodenitis, accounting for 79 (15.4), 47 (9.2%), 36 (7%), 31 (6%), 30 (5.8%), 27 (5.3%), and 26 (5.1%), respectively

caption.p: Chi-square results for association between esophageal varices group and variables

sec.p: Associations between demographic variables and esophageal varices are described in Table 3 above. Both esophageal and gastric varices were significantly associated with the recurrence of bleeding (esophageal varices: χ² = 14.8; gastric varices: χ² = 12.7). Rebleeding data are presented in Table 4:

caption.p: History of rebleeding among esophageal and gastric varices patients

sec.p: There was no statistically significant difference in mean haemoglobin at presentation between the schistosomiasis and nonschistosomiasis groups (pooled t-test, mean difference − 1.06 g/dL, 95% CI: – 2.92–0.79, p = 0.24). While some individual imputed datasets showed significant differences, the pooled analysis did not support a meaningful difference.
Mortality rates were not assessed because patients were discharged approximately 2 h after the procedure, and post-discharge follow-up was not feasible, which presents a limitation.

sec.title: Discussions
sec.p: The mean age in our study was 52 years, which is comparable to the ages of 45 and 55 years reported in Sudan and Nepal [5, 6]. Males predominated at 71%, similar to a study conducted in Saudi Arabia, which reported a male percentage of 74% [7]. Male sex was also statistically associated with esophageal varices (p < 0.05). The variation between male and female ratios was also observed in similar studies in Sudan [8, 9]. Gender-based differences in occupational and environmental exposures might contribute to this heterogeneity.

47% of the population were from Khartoum State, followed by Aljazeera (30%), which is known for its agricultural scheme, a major risk factor that makes it an endemic area with schistosomiasis. In 2021, a study reported that this endemic species migrated north towards Khartoum State as well [10].

A high esophageal varices burden in Sudan has been reported in literature [8], consisting with our findings, which reported a percentage of 60.6% as the most common endoscopic finding among patients, although a reduction in comparison to previous records was noted [9], with a history of schistosomiasis being present in 35.3% of the study population.

A figure that is lower than what was reported in previous local and regional reports. In rural sub-Saharan Africa, chronic hepatic schistosomiasis accounts for 94% of upper GI bleeders [11]. In Tanzania, active schistosomal infection accounts for approximately 48% of patients who present with haematemesis [12]. ​A study conducted in Wad Madani, Sudan, reported that 93% of patients presenting with upper GI variceal bleeding consequent to portal hypertension had a past medical history of schistosomiasis [13]. Whether this observation reflects improved public health policies, such as mass praziquantel campaigns and improved sanitation, or a selection bias, should be investigated.

The majority of those patients had previously experienced at least one similar bleeding episode, and despite the sparsity of data on long-term recurrence rates, a 3-year recurrence rate was observed. Rebleeding as 2 episodes or more was observed in 57% of the patients in one study [11], which is similar to the findings in our study (55%).

Gastric varices constituted 21% of all cases, which, in most cases, were accompanied by esophageal varices. Isolated gastric varices were found in 27 (5%) patients. These results suggest an increase in the number of gastric varices, which might be due to increased sensitivity and improved reporting of their presence. Gastritis came after, aligning with the previously published literature on the change of gastrointestinal endoscopy of the Sudanese population towards gastritis in Sudan [10]. A comparison between endoscopic profiles from different regions is described in Table 5 below.

A total of 13.3% of NSAID-takers in high-risk groups might reflect a lack of adjustment of risk factors [14]. In contrast, the number of patients who were taking beta blockers implies a pattern of noncompliance, as they were taken by 103 (20.1) individuals who presented with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Adherence to beta-blockers and medication in low-resource areas can be attributed to the inability to meet costs, inaccessibility, and lack of proper awareness. The antihypertensive and hypoglycemic drug rates were 5.8% and 5.3%, respectively, reflecting the associated comorbidities.

Findings suggest that our population is at high risk, as evidenced by the frequent presentation with moderate to severe anaemia, which is underestimated by possible selection bias after exclusion of patients with incomplete endoscopic findings because these particular groups might have presented very critically and died from severe bleeding before being stabilised for the procedure.

The fact that 20% of the study population presented with gastric varices further highlights the urgency of their presentation, as gastric varices can lead to more severe and massive gastric bleeding [15]. Both gastric and esophageal varices were found to be significantly associated with higher.ecurrence rates in our findings. The literature suggests a 93.5% recurrence rate for esophageal varices within 3 years [16]. All these factors highlight the importance of routine endoscopic screening and expanded access to secondary prophylaxis in high-risk populations.

Differences in haemoglobin values between the schistosomiasis and non-schistosomiasis groups were not detected despite assumptions about the effect of schistosomiasis on baseline haemoglobin due to sequestration and iron deficiency [17]. It is important to note that our findings represent associations only, and the cross-sectional design does not allow us to infer causality or assess long-term outcomes. These limitations should be considered when interpreting our results.

caption.p: Proportions of endoscopic findings from different studies

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: This study was held in a specialised major centre for gastroenterology, with referrals from all over the country. The sample size was relatively large and represents the last record for upper gastrointestinal bleeding in Sudan prior to the recent conflict and provides a valuable reference for future studies, and the data were treated via proper statistical methods (multiple imputations).

However, this study was conducted at a single centre, which may limit the generalisability of our findings. The retrospective design and not including all patients consecutively may introduce selection bias. We were unable to assess mortality or long-term outcomes. Despite addressing missing data using multiple imputations, this cannot fully compensate for all potential biases.

sec.title: Recommendations
sec.p: More efforts are needed to minimise schistosomiasis-related upper GI bleeding, and efforts are needed not only against a limited area but also against the entire population, as the modern lifestyle makes the spread of the endemic disease inevitable. Lifelong follow-up programs, including periodic ultrasound and endoscopy to initiate timely interventions, are recommended, especially for patients with a history of schistosomiasis or previous variceal bleeding. More studies need to be conducted to track epidemiological changes in the area to detect the postwar effects and to track the epidemiological changes associated with displacement and lack of access to healthcare

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Upper gastrointestinal bleeding in our study population is strongly associated with esophageal and gastric varices and has a high recurrence rate. Schistosomiasis remains the most common comorbid disease among upper gastrointestinal bleeding patients, which highlights the need for targeted interventions to improve outcomes in limited-resource settings. Future multi-centre and prospective studies are warranted to further detect risk factors and improve prognosis for patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding in Sudan and similar endemic regions

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Special thanks to the Department of Surgery, Al-Neelain University, and Dr. Elsaggad Eltayeb Ahmed Mohammed, consultant of general and endoscopic surgery and associate Professor of surgery, Al-Neelain University, for providing supervision and filling knowledge gaps. Additionally, we would like to thank Mohammed Salih Centre employees and doctors, especially Dr. Hani Fathi Ali Khalil, physician and gastroenterologist, at Ibn Sina Hospital.
